title: Allow control of link/copy behavior for existing paths
body:
*Issue #, if available:*
Fixes #180 

*Description of changes:*
If you used SignedRepository to link/copy targets from multiple repos into a
shared directory, these problems could occur:
* Without consistent snapshot, targets with the same name but different
  contents from different repos can overwrite each other.
* Targets with the same name and same contents from different repos can
  fail to copy/link if the file does not have write permissions.

This change addresses these related failure cases by:
* If not using consistent snapshots, we confirm that the checksum of any
  existing file matches the expected target checksum.
* Adds a `PathExists` enum that's used as a parameter to the copy/link
  functions that can be used to specify what to do with an existing
  path - skip the target, replace the existing file, or fail.

Due to the change in signature of public functions, this is a breaking
change.

*Testing done:*
As part of [this Bottlerocket PR](https://github.com/bottlerocket-os/bottlerocket/pull/964), we've tested building multiple repositories.  Without this change, we had file conflicts that caused failed builds; with this change, we're able to specify the behavior we want for shared target names and build successfully.

title: tuftool download: allow downloading specific targets
body:
**Description of changes:**

As repos grow, it becomes less practical to download all known targets.  This adds a `--target-name` / `-n` argument to `tuftool download` to allow downloading specific targets you're interested in.

**Testing done:**

Downloading all targets still works if you don't add the new argument:
```
$ cargo run -- download tmp/all \
   --metadata-url "https://updates.bottlerocket.aws/2020-02-02/aws-k8s-1.17/x86_64/" \
   --target-url "https://updates.bottlerocket.aws/targets" \
   --root "${HOME}/work/bottlerocket/packages/os/root.json"
Downloading targets to "tmp/all"
	-> manifest.json
	-> bottlerocket-aws-k8s-1.17-x86_64-0.4.1-a29a1450-root.ext4.lz4
	-> migrate_v0.4.1_pivot-repo-2020-07-07.lz4
	-> bottlerocket-aws-k8s-1.17-x86_64-0.4.1-a29a1450-boot.ext4.lz4
	-> bottlerocket-aws-k8s-1.17-x86_64-0.4.1-a29a1450-root.verity.lz4
	-> migrate_v0.4.1_add-version-lock-ignore-waves.lz4
```

Downloading only a couple targets now works:
```
$ cargo run -- download tmp/some \
   --metadata-url "https://updates.bottlerocket.aws/2020-02-02/aws-k8s-1.17/x86_64/" \
   --target-url "https://updates.bottlerocket.aws/targets" \
   --root "${HOME}/work/bottlerocket/packages/os/root.json" \
   --target-name manifest.json --target-name migrate_v0.4.1_pivot-repo-2020-07-07.lz4
Downloading targets to "tmp/some"
	-> manifest.json
	-> migrate_v0.4.1_pivot-repo-2020-07-07.lz4
```

Downloading a single target:
```
$ cargo run -- download tmp/one \
   --metadata-url "https://updates.bottlerocket.aws/2020-02-02/aws-k8s-1.17/x86_64/" \
   --target-url "https://updates.bottlerocket.aws/targets" \
   --root "${HOME}/work/bottlerocket/packages/os/root.json" \
   --target-name manifest.json
Downloading targets to "tmp/one"
	-> manifest.json
```

title: tuftool: truncate targets when downloading
body:
*Issue #, if available:*

Fixes #173 

*Description of changes:*

Use `File::create` instead of `OpenOptions` in `tuftool download`. `File::create` includes `create(true).open(true).truncate(true)` which is how we want to open our files for writing. By including `truncate(true)` the buggy behaviour seen in #173 is fixed.

*Testing*

I added an integ test of the `download` command. It adds some text to the end of one of the targets in the `outdir` after download. It then downloads the repo again and asserts the the file is correct.

This test was observed to fail before implementing the fix:

```
thread 'download_command_truncates' panicked at 'assertion failed: `(left == right)`
  left: `"This is an example target file.bloop
"`,
 right: `"This is an example target file."`: file1.txt contents do not match.', tuftool/tests/download_command.rs:34:5
```

After implementing the fix, the test passes.

title: tough and tuftool: setup logging
body:
*Issue #, if available:*

Closes #9

*Description of changes:*

Add `log` to `tough` and `simplelogger` to `tuftool`. 
I didn't add a lot of logging because I expect these to be added organically over time. I added a couple that I know will be useful to `http`. Also, from #9: 

> some outstanding events can be noted, for example removal of datastore files upon rotation.

So I added a trace in the spot that I think was being referred.

*Testing*

I used a `tuftool` download command and confirmed that it worked both with and without adding `--log-level trace`. I confirmed that `tuftool` and `tough` traces showed up, but `hyper` and `reqwest` traces did not (I think this is the desired behavior).
